Here it goes;
 
 The South has been vilified by the Northern victor since before she seceded from the Union. It has been said they were "racists" and fought for the preservation of slavery or that they were "traitors." These claims are based on nothing but propaganda issued from the printing press of the aggressor. I will prove that the South had the right to secede, the South's so-called "racism" was never as bad as the North's, and the South fought fought for the preservation of her self-determination.
 
 Secession and states' rights are two controversial subjects in American politics and government. Although they are now contentious, these were some of the guiding principles in the early days of the Union. The people of the states believed that a government closer to home, such as those in the states, had the true interest of the people in their heart. The document that declared our independence from the crown declares us to be "free and sovereign states" and have all the rights of a sovereign state. Why would the founding document of the states say the states are sovereign if a central government had the authority to push them back into line? The assertion to any casual observer that a document that is itself is declaring independence, forbids it to others. 
 
 The next document important to the development of the United States is the Articles of Confederation. In article two of the said document it states:
 
 II. Each state retains its sovereignty, freedom, and independence, and every power, jurisdiction, and right, which is not by this Confederation expressly delegated to the United States, in Congress assembled.

 If the Articles of Confederation didn't state it was perpetual, that would be enough. Explanation of the perpetuity clause; it was meant to say that the Articles didn't end just because it was passed a certain date, and need I mention that the Articles ended in 1788, after starting in 1781.
 
 Then the Constitution is the structure of the current government. In the Constitution it never declares that the states lost their sovereignty by ratifying, if that was the case I guarantee you that it wouldn't be ratified by any of the states. Many opponents of secession would say that the supremacy clause trumps this argument. This is ridiculous, the clause means that the states by ratifying are guaranteeing that they will uphold their end of the bargain, not that the federal government is supreme in all laws it passes, no matter what their contents. Otherwise Article I Section 8 is nothing but a waste of ink and parchment.
 
 The claims issued forth from Northern presses are also false when they claim that the South was motivated by "racism." If that is the case, so was the North the following is a quote from the much admired Northern general William Tecumseh Sherman: 
 
As long as a doubtful contest for supremacy exists between the two races they cannot control their choice; but as soon as we demonstrate equal courage, equal skill, superior resources, and superior tenacity of purpose, they will gradually relax and finally submit to men who profess, like myself, to fight for but one single purpose, viz, to sustain a Government capable of vindicating its just and rightful authority, independent of niggers, cotton, money, or any earthly interest.
 (O.R., Series I, Volume XXX, p. 234-235)
 
 If you don't believe he said this, go look it up in Official Record, Cornell University has it on their website. It looks like at least Sherman believes this. It is also widely acknowledged that Lincoln believed in "colonization" of the blacks, sending them back to Africa. This sounds like a policy of 19th century ethnic cleansing to me, hardly a policy of tolerance. The South on the other hand gave a plan to the European powers to recognize them in late 1864 on the basis of gradual emancipation. Why would a person fight for something it was willing to get rid of? That is a question the aggressor rarely likes to be faced with.
 
 My last point concerns the South's cause in seceding. Given the facts from the previous paragraph I feel that no significant argument is needed as to her cause. If her cause was not slavery or racism, how could anyone dispute her reason for her secession, it is a moot point. So we may philosophize about her reasons but they are really not of any note, other than to try to prevent future instances of secession.
 
 The South not only had the right to secede but wasn't motivated by "racism" or any other such cause. If you still wish to contend her cause, please elaborate on why you believe that she seceded from the Union for that purpose.

 To say that slavery was the ultimate contributing factor is ridiculous, because the war was bound to happen with or without slavery. The South was an agrarian culture that relied on cash crops to make money, while the North was an industrialized culture, that relied on Southern purchase of their products. In order to assure Northern dominance in Southern markets, they instituted the tariff that strangled Southern agriculture because of a sharp increase in the price of goods. One of Lincoln's campaign platforms was a raise in the tariff to even higher than that set in the Tariff of Abominations, which almost lead to South Carolina seceding. Since the North held a large majority in both the House and Senate, the South feared that they would take the opportunity to raise the tariff to such an extent that the Southern economy would collapse. 
 
 Most European thinkers of the time believed that this was the case. Read The Confederate Secession by the Marquis of Lothian, Google Books has a copy. It was published in 1864.
Another opinion

Europeans had their own political agendas to deal with regarding the American Civil War. From http://www.civilwarhome.com/europeandcivilwar.htm:The war had a direct bearing on the United States' foreign relations and the relations that were most important were those with the two dominant powers of Europe, England and France. Each country was a monarchy, and a monarchy does not ordinarily like to see a rebellion succeed in any land. (The example may prove contagious.) Yet the war had not progressed very far before it was clear that the ruling classes in each of these two countries sympathized strongly with the Confederacy-so strongly that with just a little prodding they might be moved to intervene and bring about Southern independence by force of arms. The South was, after all, an aristocracy, and the fact that it had a broad democratic base was easily overlooked at a distance of three thousand miles. Europe's aristocracies had never been happy about the prodigious success of the Yankee democracy. If the nation now broke into halves, proving that democracy did not contain the stuff of survival, the rulers of Europe would be well pleased.
 To be sure, the Southern nation was based on the institution of chattel slavery-a completely repugnant anachronism by the middle of the nineteenth century. Neither the British nor the French people would go along with any policy that involved fighting to preserve slavery. But up to the fall of 1862 slavery was not an issue in the war. The Federal government had explicitly declared that it was fighting solely to save the Union. If a Southern emissary wanted to convince Europeans that they could aid the South without thereby aiding slavery, he could prove his case by citing the words of the Federal President and Congress. As far as Europe was concerned, no moral issue was involved; the game of power politics could be played with a clear conscience.
 ...(once the Emancipation Proclamation was issued)...
 The government of Britain, France, or any other nation could play power politics as it chose, as long as the war meant nothing more than a government's attempt to put down a rebellion; but no government that had to pay the least attention to the sentiment of its own people could take sides against a government which was trying to destroy slavery. So, those in power in Europe did have reason to support the cause of the South for political reasons but there were initially practical considerations restraining them (miltary support of the South would mean war with the North and the secession of trade with the North, among other things), and later the Emancipation Proclamation made it politically unfeasable.
 
 As for slavery being the core cause of the Civil War, very few historians would argue that the South would have seceded even if there had been no threat to slavery. Of those Confederate states that stated their reasons for secession, the threat to slavery was listed as the main cause. Lincoln's election would have introduced the policy of new states entering the union only as non-slave-holding, thereby eventually forming a large enough majority of non-slave-holding states in Congress that would eventually vote out slavery. The Civil War was indeed fought because of the secession of the South and not initially to directly outlaw slavery, but the South seceded mainly because of the threat to slavery posed by Lincoln's election. So... no threat to slavery would have meant no Civil War. If you believe that other threats would have been strong enough to cause the South to secede, then you need to prove that.

It seems that there are two questions that are being addressed here:
 1. Was the issue of slavery the core cause of the American Civil War? As you know, my posts and Steeeeve's have argued that it was.
 
 2. Did the South have the right to cessede? This is a trickier question and I personally admit that I am not sufficiently familiar with the political / legal history of the US from the time of the Revolution to the time of the Civil War to give a definitive answer. My general understanding is that, at the founding of the US, the federal government and the Union of states in general was much looser - with States having the main political power. However, as time went on, things changed so that the power of the federal government and the strength of the union increased. So, by the time of the Civil War, there might have been enough legal / political statutes against Cessession to give the North its justification for war. However, I will leave that arguement for others who are more familiar with US political history of those times.
 
 However, it does raise an interesting general question. Namely, our political rhethoric generally does support self-determination of peoples. However, how far does this go? If a town wanted to declare itself independent of the US based on local referendum, could it? If not, why not? Some arguements concentrate on the idea that a nation's resources belong to the nation in general, not only to the local area where the resources are located (ex. the case of oil or mineral mines). I have to admit that I do not have a good answer and have mixed feelings on the subject - I support a people's right to self-determination but simultaneously recognize that, if every little group is allowed to separate from the whole, then that weakens everyone. In the case of the South, we generally find justification in the North's war to prevent the Southern cessession since it is so closely tied with the Southern support for the repugnant institution of slavery. However, the question comes up - if the South had not supported slavery, would we have agreed with its right to cessede? That is a harder question and one worth pondering.

 The abolitionist movement had strength primarily amongst the intelligencia of the South (obviously), which was a very large voting block because most owned large amounts of property (and owned slaves themselves). The state where they came the closest to implementing their policies was Virginia, just after Nat Turner's Rebellion. The rebellion put a spotlight on the issue in Virginia, and the House of Delegates took up the issue (the Senate cannot propose laws in Virginia). At the beginning of January of the year after the rebellion, the Delegates debated the issue, and a test vote came in late January. The test vote was whether to end debate, because the "slaveocrats" thought the tide was turning (the Richmond Examiner earlier in the week said that Virginia was "virtually guaranteed" to emancipate), the test vote had 13 swing votes, who supported emancipation but weren't sure if it was the time, the ultimate vote was 71-59 in favor of continuing debate, with 12/13 of the swing votes in the continuing column. The 12 swing votes were swayed the other way when the proposal called for dispersing the slaves amongst all the states.
 
 Other states took up proposals occasionally, but ended up with a similar ending.

At the beginning of January of the year after the rebellion, the Delegates debated the issue, and a test vote came in late January. The test vote was whether to end debate, because the "slaveocrats" thought the tide was turning (the Richmond Examiner earlier in the week said that Virginia was "virtually guaranteed" to emancipate), the test vote had 13 swing votes, who supported emancipation but weren't sure if it was the time, the ultimate vote was 71-59 in favor of continuing debate, with 12/13 of the swing votes in the continuing column. The 12 swing votes were swayed the other way when the proposal called for dispersing the slaves amongst all the states.
 
 Other states took up proposals occasionally, but ended up with a similar ending.

 The Nat Turner rebellion, which you say spurned on the Virginia vote, occured more than a generation earlier than the Civil War (He rebelled and was tried in 1831). It is understandable that some in the South, particularly in the state where the rebellion happened, might have wondered whether it was worth ther risk - spurring on a short-lived abolition movement. However, the conclusion that was apparently drawn both in Virginia and in the other Southern states was not to end slavery but to introduce far more stringent control of their slaves (in outlawing teaching slaves to read and write, etc.) in order to limit the threat of rebellion. So, instead of a growing abolition movement, slavery became even more entrenched in the South. If you deny this, then please point out some prominent abolition movements that were in force in the South at least into the 1850s.

Here it goes;
 ...I will prove that the South had the right to secede, the South's so-called "racism" was never as bad as the North's, and the South fought fought for the preservation of her self-determination.
I am a little late to this debate, but I just ran across it today. Lots of tangent issues have been discussed, too.
 
... The document that declared our independence from the crown declares us to be "free and sovereign states" and have all the rights of a sovereign state....
 The next document important to the development of the United States is the Articles of Confederation....
 Then the Constitution is the structure of the current government. In the Constitution it never declares that the states lost their sovereignty by ratifying, if that was the case I guarantee you that it wouldn't be ratified by any of the states.
Since the Constitution was made from the ground up, rather than amending the Articles of Confederation, I believe it became the sole governing document. It superceded all that came before it (though it contained many of the same ideas). Do the Articles of Confederation or the Declaration of Independence have standing for intepreting our laws in court? I get the idea that we agree on the Constitution being the defining document - though I think you try to use some of the language of the previous documents to, um, expand the meaning of the Constitution. I think the Constitution was a change in direction from the previous documents, toward a bigger commitment by the States. More like marriage than cohabitation. 
 
 It does not explicitly declare a loss of sovereignty, but it does place certain limits upon the States. Ratifying the Constitution was an agreement to those limits.
 
 I think these clauses do bind the States in a Union and/or prohibit secession in the manner attempted by the CSA: 
 
 "...no new State shall be formed or erected within the Jurisdiction of any other State; nor any State be formed by the Junction of two or more States, or Parts of States, without the Consent of the Legislatures of the States concerned as well as of the Congress." (We could argue about whether the word "State" would be applied to a nation state such as the CSA. The Constitution does not have a Glossary to define each term.)
 
 "No State shall enter into any Treaty, Alliance, or Confederation..." 
 
 Secession violates the terms of this contract with all the other States. Secession as an allied group of States violates even more terms. Was the Constitution a non-binding contract that anyone could ignore at will?
 
 And I am not convinced that you can guarantee how all States would have behaved. 
 
 
Many opponents of secession would say that the supremacy clause trumps this argument. This is ridiculous, the clause means that the states by ratifying are guaranteeing that they will uphold their end of the bargain, not that the federal government is supreme in all laws it passes, no matter what their contents. 

 
 This clause? "This Constitution, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, under the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land; and the Judges in every State shall be bound thereby, any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding."
 
 I think it says that the US Constitution and US Laws trump State Constitution and State Law. It does not say "no matter what their contents", it says those laws must abide by the Constitution. Has it been legally interpreted otherwise?
 
 If that is not enough, the supremacy clause is followed by a clause that applies to every legislator, governor and judge in each of the States: "The Senators and Representatives before mentioned, and the Members of the several State Legislatures, and all executive and judicial Officers, both of the United States and of the several States, shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation, to support this Constitution; " Wasn't that Oath broken in every CSA state?
 
 
Otherwise Article I Section 8 is nothing but a waste of ink and parchment.

 
 Are you saying that the Section that enumerates powers of Congress somehow trumps another section that calls US laws the supreme law of the land? The powers of Congress are broadly written, and it is hard to believe that they somehow negate another part of this same document.
 
 BTW, among those powers: "To provide for calling forth the Militia to execute the Laws of the Union, suppress Insurrections and repel Invasions;" Every State ratified this document.
 
 I cut out the "the South's so-called "racism" was never as bad as the North's" arguments. This "he did it worse than I did it" should have been countered quite simply by your Mother: "Two wrongs don't make a right".
 
 In the eyes of the public, the war was about slavery. In the eyes of the public, slavery was racist - because most slaves were black. (I think that only blacks were considered property.) In the eyes of the public, the South was more racist because of more-recent publicized history - the Jim Crow laws, one-drop laws, lynchings, school segregation and other overt, widely-publicized activities. People forget that there were slave states that did not move to secede (and were the last to abolish slavery). 
 
 I assume this issue - racism - is mentioned here in an attempt to prove that the South was right in its desire to secede, since that is part of your resolution. 
 
 
My last point concerns the South's cause in seceding.

 Excerpted from "A Declaration of the Immediate Causes which Induce and Justify the Secession of the State of Mississippi from the Federal Union":
 "Our position is thoroughly identified with the institution of slavery-- the greatest material interest of the world. Its labor supplies the product which constitutes by far the largest and most important portions of commerce of the earth. These products are peculiar to the climate verging on the tropical regions, and by an imperious law of nature, none but the black race can bear exposure to the tropical sun. These products have become necessities of the world, and a blow at slavery is a blow at commerce and civilization. That blow has been long aimed at the institution, and was at the point of reaching its consummation. There was no choice left us but submission to the mandates of abolition, or a dissolution of the Union, whose principles had been subverted to work out our ruin. 
 ...
 [The hostility to the institution of slavery] advocates negro equality, socially and politically, and promotes insurrection and incendiarism in our midst."
 
 Please read the Declarations of Georgia, Mississippi, South Carolina and Texas at 
 ht tp://sunsite.utk.edu/civil-war/reasons.html, 
 and tell me again that slavery was not a reason for secession. (Sorry, I am too new here to post a live URL.) Some searching should find the declarations of the other states, too.
 
 I am no Civil War scholar, but from what I have learned it appears that slavery was only one factor. After years of tariffs (that protected Northern manufacturers of goods, but also kept prices of those goods high) and taxes (that somehow hit Southern agriculture harder than Norther industry), the South was unhappy with their economic lot. (With so many of our Presidents having been from the South, and the rural bias that is inherent in the structure of Congress, I do not know how this situation came to be. I also think it was probably unconstitutional in structure.)
 
 However, I think that the Missouri Compromise - which had to do with slave ownership - was the spark that lit the tinder, because the South could see that their power base would only diminish. (One expected effect of this would be more pressure to abolish slavery.) Lincoln's election fanned the tinder to flames.
 
 Slavery was an economic issue for the South, and the South was already slowly moving toward abolition. (I think the rest of the Western World had eliminated slavery in the sense of ownership of a human. Ownership of another human was already an anachronism.)
 
 It appears that the Emancipation Proclamation was a tactic to prevent European aristocracy from supporting the CSA. Though Lincoln could not state that slavery was the reason for the war (for fear of losing more states to the secession attempt), by the end of the war slavery had become a major issue for the North. That is another reason that slavery sticks in people's minds as the reason for the war.
